DOC.HEAD: Titan Launch Delayed For the Eighth Time
DOC.TEXT: Stiff high altitude winds forced an eighth postponement Friday night of the launch of Martin Marietta's first commercial Titan 3 rocket carrying British and Japanese communications satellites. When the countdown reached the five-minute mark, the launch team held it there for nearly an hour while officials assessed last-minute data received from weather balloons. With the shear winds about 30,000 feet up still too high, the effort was called off once again. The launch was rescheduled for 7:07 p.m. Saturday. Liftoff originally was scheduled Dec. 7, but technical and weather problems, mainly high winds, have caused repeated delays. The rocket is to boost into orbit communications satellites for the Japanese Communications Satellite Co. and the British Ministry for Defence.
